No.518/2011 is filed by the U.P.
State Road Transport Corporation (UPSTRC) for reduction of compensation.
For the sake of convenience, the Appellants in MAC APP.

supporting_sentences.sentence: State Road Transport Corporation (UPSTRC) for reduction of compensation.

citation_contexts.raw: AM he was going on a motorcycle when he noticed a Maruti Car number DL-4C-1513 proceeding towards Mawana. When he reached near Sandhan Pulia, a U.P. Roadways bus number UP11T-1353 came from Mawana side. It was driven in a rash and negligent manner by its driver and collided with the Maruti car. Though, the witness was not cross-examined by UPSRTC as it was ordered to be proceeded ex-parte, yet the Tribunal asked several questions to satisfy itself as to the veracity of the witness. Vishakha & Ors. vs Shree Pal & Anr. on 3 January, 2012
context_window: To prove negligence, the Claimants examined Rajender Singh PW-3.
He testified that on 11.01.2009 at about 11:00 AM he was going on a motorcycle when he noticed a Maruti Car number DL-4C-1513 proceeding towards Mawana.
When he reached near Sandhan Pulia, a U.P.
Roadways bus number UP11T-1353 came from Mawana side.

supporting_sentences.sentence: He testified that on 11.01.2009 at about 11:00 AM he was going on a motorcycle when he noticed a Maruti Car number DL-4C-1513 proceeding towards Mawana.
A criminal case being FIR No.12/2009 was registered in Police Station Mawana, Meerut against Sreepal, driver of bus number UP-11T-1353.

citation_contexts.raw: s salary. 11. In National Insurance Co. Ltd. v. Indira Srivastava & Ors., 2008
context_window: As stated earlier, the salary certificate Ex.PW-2/2 was proved on record which shows that the deceased was getting a salary of `6038/-.
The Tribunal erred in excluding the bonus, conveyance allowance and other allowance from the deceased's salary.
In National Insurance Co.

supporting_sentences.sentence: The Tribunal erred in excluding the bonus, conveyance allowance and other allowance from the deceased's salary.
The allowances such as HRA, Conveyance Allowance, ESI, PF contribution and Bonus were not taken into consideration in taking the deceased's income by the Tribunal.

citation_contexts.raw: In Raj Rani v. Oriental Insurance Co. Ltd. (2009)
context_window: Different offers made to an officer by the employer, same may be either for the benefit of the employee himself or for the benefit of the entire family.

If some facilities are being provided whereby the entire family stands to benefit, the same, in our opinion, must be held to be relevant for the purpose of computation of total income on the basis whereof the amount of compensation payable for the death of the kith and kin of the applicants is required to be determined........" 12.
In Raj Rani v. Oriental Insurance Co.
Ltd.

(2009) 13 SCC 654; while relying on Indira Srivastava (supra)¸the Supreme Court reiterated that apart from Dearness Allowance other allowances payable for the benefit of the family, have to be considered for the computation of the annual income.

supporting_sentences.sentence: In Raj Rani v. Oriental Insurance Co.
In Pushpabai Purshottam Udeshi v. Ranjit Ginning & Pressing Co.

context_window: In Pushpabai Purshottam Udeshi v. Ranjit Ginning & Pressing Co.
(P) Ltd., (1977) 2 SCC 745, it was held that dearness allowance, conveyance allowance and other allowances are to be treated as part of the deceased's income.
There is distinction between the conveyance allowance and a travelling allowance.

supporting_sentences.sentence: (P) Ltd., (1977) 2 SCC 745, it was held that dearness allowance, conveyance allowance and other allowances are to be treated as part of the deceased's income.

(2009) 13 SCC 654; while relying on Indira Srivastava (supra)¸the Supreme Court reiterated that apart from Dearness Allowance other allowances payable for the benefit of the family, have to be considered for the computation of the annual income.

citation_contexts.raw: s income, but where conveyance allowance is paid apart from salary, the same may or may not be spent while travelling to the place of employment. Therefore, where conveyance allowance is paid as part of the salary, the same has to be taken into consideration for computation of the loss of dependency. Deduction towards the personal living expenses is otherwise made to calculate the dependency. Vishakha & Ors. vs Shree Pal & Anr. on 3 January, 2012 15. Now, I turn to the question whether the Claimants were to be given the benefit of future prospects. 16. Deceased was a regular employee with a Private Limited Company OM Logistics Limited. He joined as a driver on 01.04.2008 and his employment ended on 13.01.2009 because of his unfortunate death in the accident. His date of birth as per the driving licence was 15.12.1980 and his year of birth as per other documents including Ration Card was 1980
context_window: There is distinction between the conveyance allowance and a travelling allowance.

Wherever a travelling allowance is paid to an employee to perform his duties this may not be considered as the deceased's income, but where conveyance allowance is paid apart from salary, the same may or may not be spent while travelling to the place of employment.
Therefore, where conveyance allowance is paid as part of the salary, the same has to be taken into consideration for computation of the loss of dependency.
Deduction towards the personal living expenses is otherwise made to calculate the dependency.

supporting_sentences.sentence: Wherever a travelling allowance is paid to an employee to perform his duties this may not be considered as the deceased's income, but where conveyance allowance is paid apart from salary, the same may or may not be spent while travelling to the place of employment.
There is distinction between the conveyance allowance and a travelling allowance.

citation_contexts.raw: increase in the salary on account of future prospects. Although, the Tribunal applied the multiplier of 18, the same, however, has to be 17 in view of Sarla Verma & Ors. v. Delhi Transport Corporation & Anr., (2009) 6 SCC 121
context_window: Thus, the deceased's age was a little more than 28 years at the time of the accident.
Considering that the deceased was in a regular and stable employment, he was entitled to 50% increase in the salary on account of future prospects.
Although, the Tribunal applied the multiplier of 18, the same, however, has to be 17 in view of Sarla Verma & Ors.
v. Delhi Transport Corporation & Anr., (2009) 6 SCC 121, as the deceased was aged about 28 years.

supporting_sentences.sentence: Considering that the deceased was in a regular and stable employment, he was entitled to 50% increase in the salary on account of future prospects.
It is contended that the deceased was in a stable employment and was, therefore, entitled to future prospects.

supporting_sentences.sentence: (5) ` 5,85,721/- along with the proportionate interest shall be paid to Smt.
The enhanced compensation shall carry interest @ 7.5% per annum from the date of filing of the petition till the date of payment.
